Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Designs and Theory of State-Constrained Nonlinear Feedback Controls for Delay and Partial Differential Equation Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Designs and Theory of State-Constrained Nonlinear Feedback Controls for Delay and Partial Differential Equation Systems

Control systems are used to model many important engineering systems, such as electronics manufacturing processes involving lasers, marine robots that can monitor water pollution, oil drilling and refining, and rehabilitation mechanisms for patients with mobility disorders. However, many of these engineering applications involve input delays, state constraints, and uncertainties that can put them outside the scope of existing controller designs and theory. State constraints occur when the control objectives include avoiding undesirable situations such as collisions with obstacles, while input delays often arise from sensor designs or transport phenomena that make it difficult to measure the current state of the system. Also, it is inherent in many engineering applications that the control mechanisms must be autonomous. One important technique for ensuring autonomy is by using feedback control, which means that the control values must be determined from past values of the state of the system. This project will develop cutting edge feedback control designs and theory that can help address the preceding challenges, and will demonstrate the techniques in real time experiments. One key technique will involve prediction, which provides a way to use past observations from the control system to compute future states of the dynamics and future control values, even when the system involves long input delays or considerable uncertainty. As reflected in the backgrounds of the PIs, the project combines insightful engineering with sophisticated mathematics, with the goal of producing practically useful controls that have rigorous performance guarantees under delays or state constraints.

The problems to be addressed are among the most challenging and significant ones in the control engineering community. The project will strive for transformative methods, and will pursue three theoretical strategies. The first will seek generalized Lyapunov function constructions for partial differential equations, which can include extensions of current approach for building strict Lyapunov functions for ordinary differential equations to much more difficult hyperbolic partial differential equation cases. The second strategy will involve representing robust predictive controls as solutions of integral delay equations, and a dual representation in terms of perturbed first-order hyperbolic partial differential equations. Combined with the Lyapunov function constructions, this can provide robust tracking for predictively controlled nonlinear ordinary differential equations and robustness results for the corresponding partial differential equations. The third strategy will use robust forward invariance, which involves specifying the state constraints to facilitate computing maximal allowable perturbation sets to ensure safe operation under uncertainty. The project will be guided by cutting edge engineering applications, to help ensure the practical usefulness of all of the project results. The ordinary differential equation applications will involve neuromuscular electrical stimulation, which is a rehabilitation method that can help restore movement in humans with motor neuron disorders, and the control of a class of autonomous marine robots that are used for bathymetric surveys or to monitor water quality. The partial differential equation applications will involve laser pulse shaping systems that are used in the manufacture of flat panel displays or in photolithography, and a multi-phase flow system that can help mitigate the adverse effects of slugging in oil production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Control algorithms are essential for the stable, robust, and precise operation of most technological systems - from cars to mobile phones. Even though many, if not most, processes in such systems are distributed in space and require modeling using partial differential equations (PDEs), control algorithms have traditionally been developed for models given by ordinary differential equations (ODEs), which are mathematically more accessible. 

 

The PI’s breakthroughs over the last decade on control design for PDEs have enabled progress in the development of feedback algorithms without having to approximate PDE models by ODEs and incur the resulting loss in performance and possibly a loss of stability. Unlike ODEs, especially linear ones, for which general (one-size-fits-all) control design is possible, PDEs can neither be analyzed, nor can a single general control method be developed, using a universal methodology that applies to all of them. Such an attempt at universality violates both mathematics and physics (it leads, for example, to paradoxical conclusions that limits in the speed of propagation can be overcome with control). 

 

The present project has dealt with the task of expanding the classes of PDE and PDE-ODE systems for which control designs with rigorous guarantees of stability and performance are available. This quest has led in several directions. 

 

Systems of multiple coupled PDEs. For such systems, which include several coupled PDEs from the same class (such as, for example, hyperbolic) or from multiple classes (such as hyperbolic and parabolic), and containing fewer control inputs than PDEs, control designs have been developed. 

 

PDE-ODE systems. Systems that involve components that are distributed in space (flexible structures, fluids, thermal conduction, etc) and also “lumped” components (such as rigid bodies, phase interfaces, etc) require models that are hybrids of PDEs and ODEs. Such models are generalizations of traditional delay systems, with many mathematical challenges beyond the already challenging delay systems. This project has led to major advances in control for ODEs interconnected with hyperbolic or parabolic PDEs. 

 

Robustness to sampling and disturbances. The real-world application of PDE control brings the algorithms designed on this project in contact with significant additional challenges, including sampling of the measurements in time, which may be infrequent, and disturbances, which may act throughout the spatial domain or, what is worse, on the boundary of the domain. This project has resolved such challenges and has resulted in two books, one of which addresses sampled-data implementation of controllers for nonlinear delay systems and the other addresses input-to-state disturbances acting on PDEs. 

 

Applications. Applications are not only the ultimate purpose of the control designs for PDE and PDE-ODE systems but are the inspiration for the model structures considered in such research. Significant results have been developed in this project, which solve control problems in 

  • oil drilling
  • Lithium-ion batteries, 
  • age-structured bioreactors, 
  • water levels in navigable waterways with bathimetry,
  • waves in shallow canals with two stratified fluids. 

 

Dissemination and Recognitions. Besides two books, this research has produced several dozen papers published in the most prestigious journals in control systems. The PI has been recognized in the project period by numerous honors, including the ASME Oldenburger Medal, Paynter Award, Nyquist Lecture Prize, the Ragazzini Edication Award, Chestnut Textbook Prize, and the election to Fellow of SIAM, AAAS, and ASME. 

 

Student training. Graduate and undergraduate students have benefited from the efforts on the project through training, publication, and the development of expertise that has led to prestigious positions in industry and academia. The PI’s leadership in control systems education has been recognized by two of the most prestigious education awards in the control field: the Chestnut Textbook Prize and the Rafazzini Education Award.
